sect1.title: Stylesheet Customization
sect1.para: Ok, now you're nearly a docbook guru? You want to get right down to the entrails of the machinery? OK, hop on and enjoy the ride! Here are a few notes on how you should go about customizing the output. That means, changing how the pdf and html are written.

sect2.title: File hierarchy
sect2.para: The files for configuration are the following:

listitem.para: html.xsl This is where all the html specific customizations are made
pdf.xsl This is where all the pdf specific customizations are made
common.xsl This is where all the common specifications are made, ie those that go and in pdf and in html.
html.titlepage.templates.xml This is the template which modifies the html titlepage layout
pdf.titlepage.templates.xml This is the template which modifies the pdf titlepage layout

sect2.para: Please mind: The last two files are used to generate one more layer, files called html.titlepage.xsl and pdf.titlepage.xsl. The latter should not be edited, as they reflect the changes made in the former.

sect2.title: What you can change
sect2.para: Basically, in the customization layers, you have full control (just do what you want). The only thing is that each block (template, variable...) should be described by a comment. That will help later users. Long template names are not sufficient. Please take the time to state when each is used, and what it does. As customization can get cryptic, make a special effort!

sect2.title: The Bible
sect2.para: The book you want to have with you is the following: "DocBook XSL: The Complete Guide", Third Edition, by Bob Stayton, online version at http://www.sagehill.net.

Have a look at the index if you just want to change a little something in the customization. Parse through it at least once if you intend to do some heavy editing. I have found everything I needed in this book, but sometimes in unexpected sections.

Ensure no dead links exist (easy with wget --spider OR http://www.dead-links.com/ for html, harder for the pdf).
Enable the FAQ.
Use this info (google Re: Extending ulink Warren Young) to specialize ulinks in pdf/html [is it needed?].

The main files, which are produced in html by javadoc, are to be included in the pdf appendixes
Create an index, and put the main words in it
Create a reference chapter, with all the ProActive papers, and doucle check citations in manual
Add ObjectWeb on the book titlepage
Put the Part TOCs on the same page as the PART first page (it's very empty right now)

Chapter in White, on blue background

Decide how much customization should go in the CSS, and how much in the html.xsl
Images should be centered. Code borders should only wrap code, not from left to right margin.
